GOD.content: the phrase [“pardon for not meaning (to say)…”] is “up in the air”: an appearance that comes from who knows where, contingency (touch, tact, contact), & pertinent (touching, tact, contact) > dwells suspended in air, even when it touches, meteoric [both sexes], suspended like Abraham’s knife over Isaac’s head [re: scene of literature, secrecy, forgiveness]
GOD.linkedContent: the phrase [“pardon for not meaning (to say)…”] is “up in the air”: an appearance that comes from who knows where, contingency (touch, tact, contact), & pertinent (touching, tact, contact) > dwells suspended in air, even when it touches, meteoric [both sexes], suspended like Abraham’s knife over Isaac’s head [re: scene of literature, secrecy, forgiveness]

LOBL.content: contamination is not caused by contingency, contiguity, contagion but by chance
LOBL.linkedContent: contamination is not caused by contingency, contiguity, contagion but by chance

SH.content: philosophy finds itself in vicinity of poetic, of literature, the blurred border (no place, utopia) btwn empirical (contingency of the outer) and necessary (necessity of inner) > indecision of this limit most provokes thought [Derrida attacks the idea that philosophy loses itself there]
SH.linkedContent: philosophy finds itself in vicinity of poetic, of literature, the blurred border (no place, utopia) btwn empirical (contingency of the outer) and necessary (necessity of inner) > indecision of this limit most provokes thought [Derrida attacks the idea that philosophy loses itself there]

PSSS.content: psychoanalysis is ineradicable, its revolution is irreversible—yet, like civilization, it’s mortal
PSSS.linkedContent: psychoanalysis is ineradicable, its revolution is irreversible—yet, like civilization, it’s mortal

C.content: I’ll never get to the end—I’ll have to stop at a contingent moment
C.linkedContent: I’ll never get to the end—I’ll have to stop at a contingent moment

C.content: contingent: an attribute, a ration of a series; contingent touches on touch as false-contact; effects of chance, the epithet of uncalculable term (échéance), use of nonnecessary become fatal
C.linkedContent: contingent: an attribute, a ration of a series; contingent touches on touch as false-contact; effects of chance, the epithet of uncalculable term (échéance), use of nonnecessary become fatal

C.content: aleatory and inevitable: fatality of a new idiom [re: quite a few more words that’ll form a parallel series]
C.linkedContent: aleatory and inevitable: fatality of a new idiom [re: quite a few more words that’ll form a parallel series]

C.content: analogy, like the putting into series of series: can/must remain accidental
C.linkedContent: analogy, like the putting into series of series: can/must remain accidental

C.content: analogy belongs to order of contingent > appeals neither to model nor example (i.e. both Sade & Titus-Carmel ration the remainder, stage a work & jouissance re: remainder [excrement]) [Derrida is “randomly” comparing Titus-Carmel’s 127 coffins to Sade’s 120 days]
C.linkedContent: analogy belongs to order of contingent > appeals neither to model nor example (i.e. both Sade & Titus-Carmel ration the remainder, stage a work & jouissance re: remainder [excrement]) [Derrida is “randomly” comparing Titus-Carmel’s 127 coffins to Sade’s 120 days]

C.content: “things won’t stop computing in me,” Derrida wants to touch the necessity of the contingency of Titus-Carmel’s 127 coffins [compare to Lacan’s: can’t stop being-written]
C.linkedContent: “things won’t stop computing in me,” Derrida wants to touch the necessity of the contingency of Titus-Carmel’s 127 coffins [compare to Lacan’s: can’t stop being-written]

C.content: what does it mean [re: # 127 of Titus-Carmel’s 127 coffins] beyond meaningless anankē of a chance, a term (échéance), a decline (déchéance)?
C.linkedContent: what does it mean [re: # 127 of Titus-Carmel’s 127 coffins] beyond meaningless anankē of a chance, a term (échéance), a decline (déchéance)?

C.content: le M’hors-serie (I’m-out-of-series), Fors-series, the excluded necessary that marks the border of the Necessary itself: the necessary, the excepted, the contingent, sauf, fors
C.linkedContent: le M’hors-serie (I’m-out-of-series), Fors-series, the excluded necessary that marks the border of the Necessary itself: the necessary, the excepted, the contingent, sauf, fors

C.content: bananas [re: Titus-Carmel’s The Great Cultu…] would be copies of copies w/out example, phantasmata, if force of ductus did not carry the remainder beyond any phantasy, beyond the signature, proper name, nameable
C.linkedContent: bananas [re: Titus-Carmel’s The Great Cultu…] would be copies of copies w/out example, phantasmata, if force of ductus did not carry the remainder beyond any phantasy, beyond the signature, proper name, nameable

C.content: ductus’ contingency accounts for ideality of model, which always rises, fermentation of spirt (Geist), above an organic decomposition
C.linkedContent: ductus’ contingency accounts for ideality of model, which always rises, fermentation of spirt (Geist), above an organic decomposition

C.content: production of paradigm via cartouche introduces necessary (fatal) perversion that cartouche alone performs > paradigm must have been preceded by its following: phantasmatics of a contingent remaining (beyond hierarchy, beyond phantasy)
C.linkedContent: production of paradigm via cartouche introduces necessary (fatal) perversion that cartouche alone performs > paradigm must have been preceded by its following: phantasmatics of a contingent remaining (beyond hierarchy, beyond phantasy)

C.content: seal of crypt: contingent, “that’s enough” > Derrida left the seal in tact, truly, didn’t touch it
C.linkedContent: seal of crypt: contingent, “that’s enough” > Derrida left the seal in tact, truly, didn’t touch it

C.content: contingent can do w/out discourse, a masterpiece can’t do w/out a cartouche (on the market & in itself: if you insist on this distinction) > even when the cartouche remains, is defunct: pas de cartouche, plus de cartouche > what will have been able to do w/out it? never touched, aussi impassible et invulnérable qu’aux harcèlements du trait: c’est peut-être qu’il était déjà dans la tombe, le cartouche
C.linkedContent: contingent can do w/out discourse, a masterpiece can’t do w/out a cartouche (on the market & in itself: if you insist on this distinction) > even when the cartouche remains, is defunct: pas de cartouche, plus de cartouche > what will have been able to do w/out it? never touched, aussi impassible et invulnérable qu’aux harcèlements du trait: c’est peut-être qu’il était déjà dans la tombe, le cartouche

C.content: lot: chance & necessity nicely shared (bien partagée) > contingent says the same, less well, & doesn’t share
C.linkedContent: lot: chance & necessity nicely shared (bien partagée) > contingent says the same, less well, & doesn’t share

LI.content: Derrida intentionally including in his debate w/ Sarl the contingent, artificial, external (18 letters, blows)—even the amount of ink in typewriter ribbon: why not? (fringes, frames, parasites)
LI.linkedContent: Derrida intentionally including in his debate w/ Sarl the contingent, artificial, external (18 letters, blows)—even the amount of ink in typewriter ribbon: why not? (fringes, frames, parasites)

LI.content: surface of the paper, part of our calculation?
[vis-à-vis iterability altering, contaminating] no choice but to mean to say something other than what we mean to say: accident is never an accident
LI.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis iterability altering, contaminating] no choice but to mean to say something other than what we mean to say: accident is never an accident

TN.content: Nancy thinks necessity of undecidables re: thought/weight > there will be identical/analogous necessity re: subject of touching
TN.linkedContent: Nancy thinks necessity of undecidables re: thought/weight > there will be identical/analogous necessity re: subject of touching

TN.content: Franck’s forced interpretation of Husserl places hyletic sensuality of flesh (contact, self-contact) before time: Franck overruns intentional analytic toward existential one, then overruns existential analytic > flesh opens time: archefacticity as con-tingency
TN.linkedContent: Franck’s forced interpretation of Husserl places hyletic sensuality of flesh (contact, self-contact) before time: Franck overruns intentional analytic toward existential one, then overruns existential analytic > flesh opens time: archefacticity as con-tingency

TN.content: Franck’s happy, lucky condensation of word con-tingency [used as alibi?]: contingere: touching, attaining, also happening (arriver), befalling (échoir), falling to one’s lot or part (tomber en partage): essential facticity of this evenementialité aléatoire resists eidetic variation
TN.linkedContent: Franck’s happy, lucky condensation of word con-tingency [used as alibi?]: contingere: touching, attaining, also happening (arriver), befalling (échoir), falling to one’s lot or part (tomber en partage): essential facticity of this evenementialité aléatoire resists eidetic variation

TN.content: Chrétian’s contingency: experience of created humanity, historical contingency of creature that “comes after it [divine spirit],” lets itself be touched by the self-enflamed
TN.linkedContent: Chrétian’s contingency: experience of created humanity, historical contingency of creature that “comes after it [divine spirit],” lets itself be touched by the self-enflamed

TN.content: Derrida’s offering [the text] will touch Nancy in a way this is both necessary/contingent: pertinere [as necessary] doesn’t fail to touch, is cocky, arrogant, impertinent; contingency: finite being [Derrida] would like to touch a singularity [Nancy], hic et nunc, in its [his] body
TN.linkedContent: Derrida’s offering [the text] will touch Nancy in a way this is both necessary/contingent: pertinere [as necessary] doesn’t fail to touch, is cocky, arrogant, impertinent; contingency: finite being [Derrida] would like to touch a singularity [Nancy], hic et nunc, in its [his] body

TN.content: strange couple of 2 tactilities: appropriate necessity (pertinent), singulier aléatoire (contingent)
TN.linkedContent: strange couple of 2 tactilities: appropriate necessity (pertinent), singulier aléatoire (contingent)
